questions.text: A 55-year-old patient comes with hoarseness of voice and difficulty swallowing. The patient was diagnosed with laryngeal carcinoma and surgical management was done. The post-operative image of the patient is given below. Which of the following surgery was done on this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Total laryngectomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Total laryngectomy is a radical yet life-saving procedure for patients with extensive laryngeal cancer, resulting in significant anatomical and functional changes.

questions.text: Maternal antibodies do not provide significant immunity in a neonate against: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Polio

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Maternal antibodies do not provide consistent and lasting immunity against polio in neonates, necessitating early vaccination with polio drops.

questions.text: An elderly man presents with rigidity and tremors. On examination, he has blank facial expressions. Which of the following drugs can be used to manage this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Selegiline

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Selegiline is a monoamine oxidase B (MAO-B) inhibitor that increases dopamine availability in the brain and is used to manage the motor symptoms of Parkinson's disease, such as rigidity and tremors.

questions.text: Which of the following is contraindicated in a neonate with a scaphoid abdomen? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Bag & Mask ventilation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The critical point in managing a neonate with a scaphoid abdomen, particularly when a condition like CDH is suspected, involves avoiding exacerbation of the hernia through inappropriate respiratory support techniques. Opting for intubation and controlled mechanical ventilation instead of bag & mask ventilation is crucial to prevent further complications and stabilize the infant's condition. Properly securing the airway and ensuring adequate ventilation without increasing the risk of further pulmonary or gastrointestinal injury is essential in the initial management of these patients.

questions.text: A child presents to you with itchy lesions on the scalp with hair loss as shown in the image below. What would be the next best step? ( INICET Nov 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) KOH mount

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For itchy lesions on the scalp with hair loss suggestive of tinea capitis , a KOH mount is the preferred initial test to visualize fungal elements.
  • ➤ itchy lesions
  • ➤ tinea capitis
  • ➤ KOH mount
  • ➤ visualize fungal

  • ➤ Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II-9th Edition Chapter 32 Page no 32.38, 32.40

questions.text: Which of the following has familial inheritance? ( INICET May 2022) Retinoblastoma Retinitis pigmentosa Муоріа Primary open angle glaucoma
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3, 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Retinoblastoma, Retinitis pigmentosa, Myopia, and Primary open-angle glaucoma — exhibit familial inheritance patterns, meaning they can be passed down through families, indicating genetic influences.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents with fatigue and tiredness. He had low Hb and reticulocyte count. BM reveals a decrease in erythroid precursors. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Pure red cell aplasia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pure red cell aplasia is characterized by a specific decrease in erythroid precursors in the bone marrow, leading to anemia with normal WBC and platelet counts.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presented with high-grade fever, and purpuric rash as shown in the image below. CS sample showed gram-negative diplococci. Which of the following is the most likely aetiology? ( NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Neisseria meningitidis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Neisseria meningitidis is a critical pathogen to consider in young adults presenting with symptoms of high-grade fever and a purpuric rash, especially when gram-negative diplococci are identified in the CSF. Rapid diagnosis and immediate treatment with appropriate antibiotics are crucial to prevent serious complications and mortality. This highlights the importance of vigilance for meningococcal disease in acute care settings.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure. (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Internal capsule

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The internal capsule is a key white matter structure in the brain, crucial for transmitting motor and sensory information between the cerebral cortex and the spinal cord. It is located between the thalamus and the basal ganglia

questions.text: Which of the following is not a contraindication for the induction of labor? (NEET PG 2019)

options.label: D
options.text: History of lower transverse cesarean section in last two pregnancies

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Heart disease

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Cardiovascular diseases are not a contraindication for vaginal delivery. In fact, NVD is preferred in heart disease patients. The second stage of labour is cut short with the use of instrumental vaginal delivery like forceps or ventouse assisted vaginal delivery.
  • • Cardiovascular diseases are not a contraindication for vaginal delivery. In fact, NVD is preferred in heart disease patients. The second stage of labour is cut short with the use of instrumental vaginal delivery like forceps or ventouse assisted vaginal delivery.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Pelvic tumor : Pelvic tumor if diagnosed may interfere with normal labor and needs to be evaluated before deciding the mode of delivery
  • • Option A. Pelvic tumor
  • • Option B. Herpes infection : Active herpes is an absolute contra-indication to a normal delivery due to the high viral shedding in the lesions and increased risk of neonatal herpes.
  • • Option B. Herpes infection
  • • Option D. History of lower transverse cesarean section in last two pregnancies : History of 2 or more previous cesareans is also a contra-indication to a vaginal delivery and hence induction is not done
  • • Option D. History of lower transverse cesarean section in last two pregnancies

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cardiovascular diseases are not a contraindication for vaginal delivery, and NVD is preferred in heart disease patients.
  • ➤ Cardiovascular diseases are not a contraindication for vaginal delivery, and NVD is preferred in heart disease patients.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 332, Dc Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 332, Dc Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8 th edition

questions.text: A patient presents with a history of penetrating injury to the eye. A diagnosis of sympathetic ophthalmitis was confirmed. Which of the following will be seen? ( NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Panuveitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sympathetic ophthalmitis is a granulomatous panuveitis that occurs after penetrating eye injuries or intraocular surgeries, affecting both the injured and uninjured eyes. It involves inflammation of the entire uveal tract and is characterized by features such as Dalen-Fuch's nodules and retrolental flare in the uninjured eye.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented with a lower abdominal mass and lower abdominal discomfort. On examination, the uterus appears uniformly enlarged and adnexa is free. MRI shows the presence of a myometrial cyst. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Adenomyosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Adenomyosis is the presence of endometrial tissue in the myometrium. The uterus is generally uniformly enlarged up to 12-14 weeks size and can be tender on examination. Investigation of choice: Ultrasound On ultrasound, the following can be seen in adenomyosis:
  • • Adenomyosis is the presence of endometrial tissue in the myometrium. The uterus is generally uniformly enlarged up to 12-14 weeks size and can be tender on examination.
  • • Investigation of choice: Ultrasound
  • • On ultrasound, the following can be seen in adenomyosis:
  • • Management of adenomyosis Medical management: For symptomatic relief Total Hysterectomy (Definitive treatment - Treatment of choice if family is complete)
  • • Management of adenomyosis Medical management: For symptomatic relief Total Hysterectomy (Definitive treatment - Treatment of choice if family is complete)
  • • Medical management: For symptomatic relief Total Hysterectomy (Definitive treatment - Treatment of choice if family is complete)
  • • Medical management: For symptomatic relief
  • • Total Hysterectomy (Definitive treatment - Treatment of choice if family is complete)
  • • Other options
  • • Other options
  • • Option A. Endometriosis : This presents as 5Ds (Dysmenorrhoea, Dyspareunia, Dyschezia, Dysfertility and Dull-aching abdominal pain). Diagnostic modality of choice is laparoscopy. Myometrial cysts are not seen. Endometriotic (chocolate) cysts in the ovary may be seen.
  • • Option A. Endometriosis
  • • Option C. Leiomyoma : Fibroids or leiomyomas usually present with menorrhagia and dysmenorrhoea. If very large, they will present with abdominal mass and pelvic pressure. On ultrasound, depending on the location, well circumscribed rounded lesions are seen.
  • • Option C. Leiomyoma
  • • Option D. Endometrial hyperplasia : This will present as menorrhagia. On ultrasound the endometrium will be thickened.
  • • Option D. Endometrial hyperplasia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Adenomyosis is characterized by a uniformly enlarged uterus with myometrial cysts, diagnosed primarily via ultrasound.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 196, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 196, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6 th edition

questions.text: All are true regarding peripartum cardiomyopathy except? (NEET PG 2018)

options.label: A
options.text: Development of cardiac failure within 5 months of delivery

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Left ventricular diastolic dysfunction

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Peripartum cardiomyopathy (PPCM) is a form of heart failure that occurs during the last month of pregnancy or within five months postpartum. It is characterized by left ventricular systolic dysfunction, rather than diastolic dysfunction. The diagnostic criteria for PPCM include:
  • • Cardiac failure developing in the last month of pregnancy or within five months after delivery. Absence of an identifiable cause for the cardiac failure. Absence of recognizable heart disease prior to the last month of pregnancy. Echocardiographic evidence of left ventricular systolic dysfunction (ejection fraction <45% or fractional shortening <30%) along with a dilated left ventricle.
  • • Cardiac failure developing in the last month of pregnancy or within five months after delivery.
  • • Absence of an identifiable cause for the cardiac failure.
  • • Absence of recognizable heart disease prior to the last month of pregnancy.
  • • Echocardiographic evidence of left ventricular systolic dysfunction (ejection fraction <45% or fractional shortening <30%) along with a dilated left ventricle.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Development of cardiac failure within 5 months of delivery : Correct. PPCM develops within five months of delivery.
  • • Option A. Development of cardiac failure within 5 months of delivery
  • • Option C. Absence of identifiable cause : Correct. PPCM is diagnosed in the absence of an identifiable cause for cardiac failure.
  • • Option C. Absence of identifiable cause
  • • Option D. Dilated left ventricle : Correct. PPCM is associated with a dilated left ventricle.
  • • Option D. Dilated left ventricle

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Peripartum cardiomyopathy is characterized by left ventricular systolic dysfunction and occurs within the last month of pregnancy or up to five months postpartum, in the absence of an identifiable cause for cardiac failure.
  • ➤ Ref: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK482185/
  • ➤ Ref: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK482185/

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding an allosteric modifier? (NEET PG 2018)

options.label: B
options.text: Causes the enzyme to work faster only

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Participates in feedback regulation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Allosteric Regulation
  • ➤ Allosteric Regulation
  • ➤ Allosteric enzyme has one catalytic site where the substrate binds and another separate allosteric site where the modifier binds (allo = other). Allosteric and substrate binding sites may or may not be physically adjacent. The binding of the regulatory molecule can either enhance the activity of the enzyme ( allosteric activation ), or inhibit the activity of the enzyme ( allosteric inhibition ). In the former case, the regulatory molecule is known as the positive modifier and in the latter case as the negative modifier . The binding of substrate to one of the subunits of the enzyme may enhance substrate binding by other subunits. This effect is said to be positive cooperativity . If the binding of substrate to one of the subunits decreases the avidity of substrate binding by other sites, the effect is called negative cooperativity. In feedback mechanism, one of the intermediates or products will go back and bind to the allosteric site of one of the enzymes involved in the series of reactions, thereby either inhibiting or activating the enzyme.
  • ➤ Allosteric enzyme has one catalytic site where the substrate binds and another separate allosteric site where the modifier binds (allo = other).
  • ➤ one catalytic site
  • ➤ separate allosteric site
  • ➤ Allosteric and substrate binding sites may or may not be physically adjacent.
  • ➤ The binding of the regulatory molecule can either enhance the activity of the enzyme ( allosteric activation ), or inhibit the activity of the enzyme ( allosteric inhibition ).
  • ➤ allosteric activation
  • ➤ allosteric inhibition
  • ➤ In the former case, the regulatory molecule is known as the positive modifier and in the latter case as the negative modifier .
  • ➤ positive modifier
  • ➤ negative modifier
  • ➤ The binding of substrate to one of the subunits of the enzyme may enhance substrate binding by other subunits. This effect is said to be positive cooperativity . If the binding of substrate to one of the subunits decreases the avidity of substrate binding by other sites, the effect is called negative cooperativity.
  • ➤ positive cooperativity
  • ➤ negative cooperativity.
  • ➤ In feedback mechanism, one of the intermediates or products will go back and bind to the allosteric site of one of the enzymes involved in the series of reactions, thereby either inhibiting or activating the enzyme.

questions.text: A primigravida woman at 12 weeks of gestation comes to the antenatal clinic for nutritional advice. Which of the following will you recommend? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Additional 300kcal in 2nd trimester

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • For a pregnant woman, additional caloric intake recommendations vary by trimester. As per Williams Obstetrics: In the first trimester, no extra calories are required. In the second trimester, it is recommended to increase by approximately 340 kcal per day. In the third trimester, it is recommended to increase by approximately 452 kcal per day. According to the Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR), an additional intake of 300 kcal during the second and third trimesters of pregnancy is recommended. Therefore, the recommendation of an additional 300 kcal in the second trimester is appropriate.
  • • For a pregnant woman, additional caloric intake recommendations vary by trimester.
  • • As per Williams Obstetrics: In the first trimester, no extra calories are required. In the second trimester, it is recommended to increase by approximately 340 kcal per day. In the third trimester, it is recommended to increase by approximately 452 kcal per day.
  • • In the first trimester, no extra calories are required. In the second trimester, it is recommended to increase by approximately 340 kcal per day. In the third trimester, it is recommended to increase by approximately 452 kcal per day.
  • • In the first trimester, no extra calories are required.
  • • In the second trimester, it is recommended to increase by approximately 340 kcal per day.
  • • In the third trimester, it is recommended to increase by approximately 452 kcal per day.
  • • According to the Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR), an additional intake of 300 kcal during the second and third trimesters of pregnancy is recommended.
  • • Therefore, the recommendation of an additional 300 kcal in the second trimester is appropriate.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Additional 300kcal in 1st trimester: No extra calories are recommended in the first trimester.
  • • Option B. Additional 300kcal in 1st trimester:
  • • Option C. Additional 400kcal in 3rd trimester: The recommendation for the third trimester is an increase of approximately 452 kcal per day.
  • • Option C. Additional 400kcal in 3rd trimester:
  • • Option D. Additional 300kcal throughout the pregnancy: Caloric requirements vary by trimester, with no extra calories needed in the first trimester, and specific increases for the second and third trimesters.
  • • Option D. Additional 300kcal throughout the pregnancy:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand the caloric requirements and recommendations for each trimester of pregnancy to ensure adequate maternal and fetal nutrition.
  • ➤ Ref: Page 483, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 483, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

options.label: D

Ans. D) Suspicion of Laryngeal carcinoma planned for surgery later

questions.text: A patient comes with palpitation to ER. His Pulse-180/min and BP-70mm of Hg systolic. ECG shows narrow QRS complex tachycardia with regular heart rate. What is the next step in management? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) DC cardioversion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ DC cardioversion is the emergency treatment of choice for a patient with hemodynamically unstable narrow QRS complex tachycardia, as it quickly restores normal rhythm and stabilizes the patient.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison 21/Cardiology/SVT/chap 246

questions.text: Match the following disorders causing secondary amenorrhea with their respective lab findings: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1-A, 2-D, 3-C, 4-B

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Secondary amenorrhea is the absence of menses for more than three months in girls or women who previously had regular menstrual cycles or six months in girls or women who had irregular menses. Premature Ovarian failure: FSH and LH levels will be very high, estrogen levels are low Asherman's syndrome: As the cause in the endometrium, hormonal levels are normal. PCOS: Alteration in the LH/FSH ratio Sheehan's syndrome/ pituitary apoplexy: Hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism: So FSH and LH are low and so is Estrogen
  • • Secondary amenorrhea is the absence of menses for more than three months in girls or women who previously had regular menstrual cycles or six months in girls or women who had irregular menses.
  • • Premature Ovarian failure: FSH and LH levels will be very high, estrogen levels are low
  • • Asherman's syndrome: As the cause in the endometrium, hormonal levels are normal.
  • • PCOS: Alteration in the LH/FSH ratio
  • • Sheehan's syndrome/ pituitary apoplexy: Hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism: So FSH and LH are low and so is Estrogen

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To correctly diagnose the underlying cause of secondary amenorrhea, it is essential to understand and interpret the hormonal profiles associated with different conditions:
  • ➤ Premature Ovarian Failure: Elevated FSH and LH levels with decreased estradiol indicate ovarian insufficiency. Asherman Syndrome: Low levels of FSH, LH, and estradiol suggest an endometrial cause, such as scarring. PCOS (Polycystic Ovary Syndrome): Typically characterized by normal FSH, elevated LH, and normal estradiol levels, reflecting an imbalance in gonadotropins. Sheehan Syndrome: Normal levels of FSH, LH, and estradiol are indicative of pituitary insufficiency, where the pituitary gland fails to stimulate the ovaries.
  • ➤ Premature Ovarian Failure: Elevated FSH and LH levels with decreased estradiol indicate ovarian insufficiency.
  • ➤ Premature Ovarian Failure:
  • ➤ Asherman Syndrome: Low levels of FSH, LH, and estradiol suggest an endometrial cause, such as scarring.
  • ➤ Asherman Syndrome:
  • ➤ PCOS (Polycystic Ovary Syndrome): Typically characterized by normal FSH, elevated LH, and normal estradiol levels, reflecting an imbalance in gonadotropins.
  • ➤ PCOS (Polycystic Ovary Syndrome):
  • ➤ Sheehan Syndrome: Normal levels of FSH, LH, and estradiol are indicative of pituitary insufficiency, where the pituitary gland fails to stimulate the ovaries.
  • ➤ Sheehan Syndrome:
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3 rd edition Pg 380,
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3 rd edition Pg 380,

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a severe headache is scheduled to undergo a CT scan. During history taking, which of the following will you definitely ask for before the commencement of the scan? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) LMP

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The most important information to obtain during a history in a 28-year-old woman of reproductive age who has been referred for a CT scan is the last menstrual period (LMP). Since it is imperative to rule out pregnancy before taking a CT scan, last menstrual period is the most appropriate answer to this question.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Use of cochlear implant: While important in MRI to prevent damage to the implant from the magnetic field, it is not typically a concern in CT scans which use X-rays.
  • • Option A. Use of cochlear implant:
  • • Option C. History of fall: Although relevant to the medical history, it is not critical specifically before a CT scan unless symptoms suggest complications that a CT scan could exacerbate.
  • • Option C. History of fall:
  • • Option D. History of hypertension: Important in overall patient assessment but does not directly influence the decision to perform a CT scan as critically as confirming pregnancy status does.
  • • Option D. History of hypertension:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Inquiring about the Last Menstrual Period (LMP) is essential for any woman of childbearing age before undergoing diagnostic procedures involving radiation, such as a CT scan, to avoid potential harm to an unborn baby.

questions.text: Which of the following are the objective tests for the hearing? ( INICET May 2021) BERA (Brainstem evoked response audiometry) OAE (Otoacoustic emission) PTA (Pure tone audiometry) Tympanometry
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Objective hearing tests like BERA, OAE, and Tympanometry provide essential diagnostic information without the need for patient interaction, distinguishing them from subjective tests like Pure Tone Audiometry which rely on patient responses.

questions.text: Identify the correct sequence of the family cycle.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Formation → extension → contraction → dissolution

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The family cycle consists of the following 6 stages in the correct sequence:
  • • Formation: From marriage until the birth of the first child. Extension : From the birth of the first child until the birth of the last child. Complete Extension - From the birth of the last child until the first child leaves home Contraction: from first child leaves home to the last child leaves home Complete contraction: from last child leave home to the death of first spouse Dissolution: From the death of the first spouse until the death of the surviving spouse.
  • • Formation: From marriage until the birth of the first child.
  • • Formation:
  • • Extension : From the birth of the first child until the birth of the last child.
  • • Extension
  • • Complete Extension - From the birth of the last child until the first child leaves home
  • • Contraction: from first child leaves home to the last child leaves home
  • • Contraction:
  • • Complete contraction: from last child leave home to the death of first spouse
  • • Dissolution: From the death of the first spouse until the death of the surviving spouse.
  • • Dissolution:
  • • The correct sequence is formation, extension, contraction, and finally, dissolution.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct sequence of the family cycle is formation, extension, complete extension, contraction, complete contraction and dissolution, representing the stages from marriage to the death of the surviving spouse.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman presents with altered sensorium, breathlessness, hypotension, and bradycardia. Examination revealed non-pitting edema of the extremities. She has a long-standing history of weight gain, constipation, cold intolerance, and menorrhagia. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Myxedema coma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Myxedema coma is a severe, life-threatening condition of profound hypothyroidism, characterized by symptoms such as altered sensorium, bradycardia, hypotension, and non-pitting edema. Immediate treatment involves IV thyroxine and IV hydrocortisone to manage both thyroid and potential adrenal insufficiency

questions.text: CRISPR-Cas9 is used for which of the following? (FMGE JULY 2024)

questions.text: A patient underwent surgery for indirect inguinal hernia with mesh repair. The most commonly damaged nerve in this surgery is: (FMGE JULY 2024)

questions.text: A patient with bloody diarrhea. Flask-shaped ulcers seen. Infection due to ingestion of quadrinucleate cysts. What is the appropriate treatment? (FMGE JULY 2024)

questions.text: Which of the following has highest glycemic index: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Glucose

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Glucose is often used as the standard reference for measuring the glycemic index, with a value set at 100. It is absorbed rapidly into the bloodstream, causing a quick and significant increase in blood sugar levels. Thus, it has the highest glycemic index among the options listed.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Fructose: Fructose has a lower glycemic index compared to glucose. This is because fructose is metabolized differently, primarily in the liver, and leads to a slower and lower rise in blood glucose levels compared to glucose.
  • • Option B. Fructose:
  • • Option C. Sucrose: Sucrose, or table sugar, is a disaccharide composed of glucose and fructose. Its glycemic index is lower than that of pure glucose because the presence of fructose moderates the overall blood sugar response.
  • • Option C. Sucrose:
  • • Option D. Sugar Alcohols: Sugar alcohols, such as xylitol, sorbitol, and mannitol, generally have lower glycemic indices than glucose. They are absorbed more slowly and incompletely in the intestine, leading to a lesser impact on blood sugar levels.
  • • Option D. Sugar Alcohols:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glycemic index (GI) - This is the increase in blood glucose after the test dose of a carbohydrate compared with that of an equivalent amount of glucose. GI is a value assigned to foods based on how slowly or how quickly those foods cause an increase in blood glucose levels.
  • ➤ Glycemic index (GI)
  • ➤ GI measures sugar in the blood (only glucose). It does not measure fructose or glucose - fructose blends. The highest glycemic index is for glucose & galactose (Also, maltose, trehalose & isomaltose get converted to glucose, so they also have high GI). Also, lactose is broken down to glucose and galactose, so has high GI. This is because glucose and galactose are absorbed from intestine via SGLT-1, which is active transport and absorbs all of glucose & galactose, even against the concentration gradient. Fructose and sugar alcohols have less glycemic index because they are not absorbed completely (because glucose transporter is GLUT-5, which absorbs fructose only down the concentration gradient). HFCS (High Fructose Corn Syrup)- 58% glucose, Sucrose (50% glucose) gets split into glucose, so have high GI (HFCS & Sucrose has fructose as the other component).
  • ➤ GI measures sugar in the blood (only glucose). It does not measure fructose or glucose - fructose blends.
  • ➤ The highest glycemic index is for glucose & galactose (Also, maltose, trehalose & isomaltose get converted to glucose, so they also have high GI). Also, lactose is broken down to glucose and galactose, so has high GI. This is because glucose and galactose are absorbed from intestine via SGLT-1, which is active transport and absorbs all of glucose & galactose, even against the concentration gradient.
  • ➤ highest glycemic index
  • ➤ glucose & galactose
  • ➤ Fructose and sugar alcohols have less glycemic index because they are not absorbed completely (because glucose transporter is GLUT-5, which absorbs fructose only down the concentration gradient).
  • ➤ Fructose and sugar alcohols
  • ➤ less glycemic index
  • ➤ HFCS (High Fructose Corn Syrup)- 58% glucose, Sucrose (50% glucose) gets split into glucose, so have high GI (HFCS & Sucrose has fructose as the other component).
  • ➤ GI of Glucose = 100 % or 1 GI of Fructose = 25 % GI of Sucrose = 65 %
  • ➤ GI of Glucose = 100 % or 1
  • ➤ GI of Glucose
  • ➤ GI of Fructose = 25 %
  • ➤ GI of Fructose
  • ➤ GI of Sucrose = 65 %
  • ➤ GI of Sucrose
  • ➤ Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 528
  • ➤ Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 528

questions.text: Which of the following types of renal stones are produced by laxative abuse? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Ammonium urate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Laxative abuse can lead to metabolic alkalosis, which creates an alkaline urinary environment, predisposing to the formation of ammonium urate stones.

questions.text: A patient has liver damage. His eyes examination showed the given picture. Patient also had neurological manifestations. Which factor is responsible for his disease? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Copper

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The described clinical picture is highly suggestive of Wilson's disease, a genetic disorder of copper metabolism. In Wilson's disease, there is an accumulation of copper in various tissues, including the liver and brain, leading to liver damage and neurological symptoms. The eye examination often reveals Kayser-Fleischer rings, a characteristic sign involving copper deposition in the cornea.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Galactose: While disorders in galactose metabolism, such as galactosemia, can cause liver damage, they do not typically present with the specific eye findings or the same neurological manifestations described in the scenario. Galactosemia usually presents in infancy with symptoms like oil drop cataract, failure to thrive, jaundice, and feeding difficulties.
  • • Option B. Galactose:
  • • Option C. Mannose: Mannose metabolism disorders are rare and do not typically present with liver damage, neurological symptoms, and eye changes as described. These disorders often have different clinical manifestations, including developmental delay and immune dysfunction.
  • • Option C. Mannose:
  • • Option D. Glucose: While diabetes (a disorder of glucose metabolism) can lead to liver damage and may have ocular manifestations (like diabetic retinopathy), it does not typically present with Kayser-Fleischer rings or the described neurological symptoms.
  • • Option D. Glucose:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Kayser-Fleischer ring shown in the image occurs in Wilson disease. This disease is caused by mutations in a copper-binding ATPase which leads to copper storage in the eye (Kayser-Fleischer ring), liver (hepatitis and cirrhosis) and brain (psychosis).
  • ➤ Kayser-Fleischer ring shown in the image occurs in Wilson disease.
  • ➤ This disease is caused by mutations in a copper-binding ATPase which leads to copper storage in the eye (Kayser-Fleischer ring), liver (hepatitis and cirrhosis) and brain (psychosis).
  • ➤ copper storage

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis in the image given below? ( NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Dermoid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Recognizing and differentiating between various ocular surface lesions is crucial for appropriate diagnosis and management. This involves understanding their typical presentations, etiologies, and potential complications. Regular eye examinations and proper eye protection, especially from UV light, are important for eye health.

questions.text: An adolescent fell on an outstretched hand. For management, the doctor ties a cast as shown in the given image. Which fracture did the patient suffer from? (FMGE 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Scaphoid fracture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For the treatment of undisplaced and stable scaphoid fractures, a glass-holding cast is applied.

questions.text: What is the investigation of choice in varicose vein? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Duplex scan

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The duplex scan is the investigation of choice for varicose veins, providing detailed information on venous blood flow and identifying sites of venous incompetence.

questions.text: A young woman was found dead at home under mysterious circumstances. Her live-in partner was reported missing. These were the postmortem images taken by the forensic photographer. Which of the following is the likely cause of her death? ( INICET Nov 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Throttling involves manual strangulation by applying pressure to the neck, causing bruises, abrasions, and contusions, and can lead to death by occlusion of blood supply or airway and pressure on the carotid sinus.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely tumor arising from the slide shown in the image? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Adenocarcinoma is identified by the presence of glandular formations in histopathological slides.

questions.text: A young male is complaining of pain, and the image shows a lesion in the diaphysis. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Osteoid osteoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ When encountering a patient with localized bone pain and a small radiolucent lesion in the cortex of the bone, consider osteoid osteoma in the differential diagnosis. Early and accurate diagnosis can lead to effective treatment, primarily with NSAIDs or surgical excision, providing significant symptom relief.
  • ➤ When encountering a patient with localized bone pain and a small radiolucent lesion in the cortex of the bone, consider osteoid osteoma in the differential diagnosis. Early and accurate diagnosis can lead to effective treatment, primarily with NSAIDs or surgical excision, providing significant symptom relief.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child has difficulty walking and getting up from a squatting position. A muscle biopsy was done and is as shown in the image. Which of the following is true about this condition? (NEET PG 2022)

options.label: C
options.text: It is a mitochondrial storage disorder

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Death occurs in 3rddecade

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is a genetic disorder characterized by progressive muscle weakness, and death typically occurs in the late teens to early 20s.
